summary_comment: Professor Lekies is known for being approachable and knowledgeable, particularly in rural sociology, though her classes can be disorganized and sometimes monotonous. Students appreciate her helpfulness and the interesting topics, but often find the excessive writing requirements and unclear expectations challenging. Her teaching style and organization vary among students, with some finding her classes easy and well-structured, while others struggle with disorganization and difficulty staying engaged.
summary_comment_short: Professor Lekies is known for being kind and knowledgeable, with a clear interest in her subject matter, particularly rural sociology. However, students often find her classes disorganized, with frequent attendance checks and unclear expectations, and some report that lectures can be long and unengaging.

Ratings.comment: I actually took ENR5640 with her. She is very kind and easy to talk to, but the amount of writing that we have to do feels unnecessary. The class is also somewhat disorganized in that it's a lot of guest speakers and it can be hard to tell sometimes what we're actually supposed to be absorbing.

Dr. Lekies is super nice and knowledgeable but lectures are long and boring. The final project parts were delayed by at least 3 weeks and it was confusing on what the project was and what we had to submit. TAs didn't know how to grade so she would have to go back through and regrade everything. For exams, I studied quizlets a girl made and passed.

The topics she teaches are interesting, but her class is very boring. She had random attendance checks once a week for a class held twice a week; wasn't great at answering questions. Her slides have topic titles but no information- have to figure things out yourself. If you don't show up, you won't understand. Not tech savvy at all

It's obvious her specialty and interest is in rural sociology, not in statistics. She's generally pretty nice, and was merciful during COVID-19, but she's not the best at answering questions online or in person.

Attendance is kind of mandatory for her classes (has random attendance checks, so you don't know). Rural soc is honestly easy if you just pay attention during class and complete the assignments. You can tell Lekies is interested in her topic and knows a lot, however, it isn't the most entertaining or engaging class. Easy to fall asleep if tired.

I loved this professor, she made the material so easy to understand and was very helpful. There are homeworks every week. As long as you go to class and pay attention you'll be fine. The lab for the class i found pointless and unconnected to the lecture course. Attendance for that is mandatory as well. The material was very easy i thought.

I highly recommend taking this class with Dr. Lekies. It is easy and she is really nice. The exams are what you'd expect and the content is very interesting. She doesn't post her full lectures online, so either show up or find a friend in the class. Overall, very chill class, and Dr. Lekies is also very laid-back. Also, no textbook required

One of the best classes I've taken at OSU.  The lectures were interesting, the material, and class in general, were very well organized.  Yes, we had tests, and yes they were difficult if you did not take the time to prepare, but the quality of information and structure of the class were better than most.  Great teacher!

The only professor that gives exams in class. My friends in other 1500classes all took the exam and quizzes online. 3 assignments through out the semester, not much, but still need time to think otherwise won't get good grade. Terrible lecturer, never post power points and just show a slide that has large amount of information for like ten seconds.
hard to pass. attendence check randomly. gives low grades in assignments. don't choose her class!!!!!

summary_comment: Professor Berardo is highly regarded for his engaging lectures and clear explanations, making even potentially dull topics interesting. Students appreciate his approachability and willingness to provide feedback, though they note that class attendance and consistent engagement with the material are crucial for success. Grading is based on frequent quizzes, exams, and a policy brief, with a heavy emphasis on class participation and preparation.
summary_comment_short: Professor Berardo is highly regarded for his engaging lectures and clear teaching style, making complex topics accessible and interesting. Students appreciate his availability and fairness in grading, though they note that class attendance and consistent performance on weekly quizzes are crucial for success.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Berardo is a hilarious dude who's very knowledgeable about what he teaches. Grading is based off weekly online quizzes, two exams, and a policy brief at the end of the class. Reading isn't too long, but you absolutely want to do it as it's primarily where exam questions come from. If you don't go to class you'll struggle, but he wants to help.

Ramiro was by far the most interesting professor I've had at OSU. He makes boring content exciting, and is clear about expectations. There are only 4 things graded over the semester, so you definitely have to study for exams. He is approachable both inside and outside of class. Attendance not mandatory, but won't pass without going.

Definitely one of my favorite professors! I would say he's perfect but his class structure makes me want to rip my hair out. Your grade is so heavily dependent on biweekly quizzes with only a few questions, so if you miss one question you're toast! Your grade could drop a whole letter because you miss a few questions on back to back quizzes
If you participate in class and go talk to him he'll be your favorite professor. Very helpful and available to give feedback on grades.

I actually took him for ENR 3200, but that wasn't an option. He is a great professor who really cares about what he teaches. The topic could have been extremely boring, but he made it engaging and made you care. He is a tough but fair grader, if you go to lecture and put in effort on exams and projects you will pass.

One of the coolest professors I've had at OSU. Really funny and cares about his students & getting honest feedback to improve the class. Attendance isn't mandatory, but going to lecture is really helpful for the exams. Tough, but fair grader. Weekly reading+quizzes were kinda dry, but related to class well. Lectures were pretty interesting.

One of my favorite professors at OSU. His class was easily my favorite of the semester even though it was the hardest. Make you work for your grade but he's fair. Attending lecture isn't mandatory, but I don't think you'll get a good grade unless you come to class

Dr. Berardo has been my favorite professor thus far at OSU. He lays everything out from the beginning and is extremely clear and fair. He is a great lecturer. I was skeptical when I began this course. I expected the material to  be dry and uninteresting. Well, the readings were a bit of a bore, but he made you care! Seriously, he is wonderful.
Nice guy, tough but fair. Funny!

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Research Design for the Environmental Social Sciences

summary_comment: Professor Karns is highly regarded for his deep care and commitment to his students, making his classes both challenging and enjoyable. Students appreciate his insightful feedback, especially in revising papers for the final exam, and find him to be a humorous and engaging instructor, particularly excelling in making complex subjects accessible.
summary_comment_short: Professor Karns is highly regarded for his deep care for students and effective teaching methods, which make learning both enjoyable and challenging. His insights are valuable, and while his classes can be demanding, students find them rewarding and often hilarious.

Ratings.comment: Wonderful professor who deeply cares about his students. I learned a lot in his class about writing and he does it in a enjoyable format. It is although seemly difficult to get a perfect on an assignment but gives the grade you earned
almost never grades 100% but you get to revise some papers for the final exam, very kind and understanding, did very well with the transfer to online school all things considered.
Absolutely LOVED taking my senior capstone with Dr. Karns. He gave my group amazing feedback and is so funny. He is extremely insightful and overall a gem for ENR students.

Take Wildlife Management at PLE with Gabe!!!! Class is so fun, only first week is lecture heavy, second week you are in field doing a project you design with a group and third week you go on a camping trip. Class is an easy A and super fun.

He's a really great guy! class was unorganized but this wasn't his typical class he usually teaches. exams were a bit confusing because there wasn't any real structure to them except general topics like "the lacy act" and "the ESA" during class notes were hard to get because we would venture off in impromptu discussions.

I'm a fifth-year senior and Dr. Karns is by far the best professor I've ever had. Not only is he a fantastic professor, he is absolutely hilarious and makes a tough class enjoyable. He is helpful, clear, and knowledgeable. He brings his wealth of knowledge to a simplistic level that can be understood easily by students. I

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Environment and Natural Resources Management for Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Communicating Environmental and Natural Resources Information

SEI.Class Name: Environment and Natural Resources Management for Forestry Fisheries and Wildlife

SEI.Class Name: Environment and Natural Resources Management for Forestry Fisheries and Wildlife

SEI.Class Name: Communicating Environmental and Natural Resources Information

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Environment and Natural Resources Management for Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

summary_comment: Professor Campbell is highly regarded for his knowledge and passion for the subject, often described as caring and respectful. However, his teaching approach, which heavily emphasizes group projects and extensive writing assignments, is polarizing, with many students finding it challenging and time-consuming. While some appreciate the depth of learning and the opportunity to engage deeply with the material, others struggle with the workload and find his lectures and class structure less effective.
summary_comment_short: Professor Campbell is highly regarded for his depth of knowledge and passion for the subject matter, though his teaching style and class structure, particularly the extensive group projects and heavy workload, can be challenging and off-putting for some students. His approach is effective for those who thrive in collaborative environments and value thorough, detailed learning experiences.

Ratings.comment: This subject matter is just not for me. I took his community development class which was required. The whole class is one giant group project where you have a community that is made up and you have to make up all the details and come up with a community development plan and I hate it and I cant wait to never think about it again. He cares too much

Dr. Campbell is great and very knowledgeable. He is very nice and friendly to his students and considerate when you talk to him about your needs. His class is amazing & I found it to be interesting, although I understand that the group work can be a turn-off for others, I personally enjoyed it and found it to be a very valuable learning experience.

Dr. Campbell was really nice, respectful, and was passionate about what he was talking about. The class is structured around one large, joint-proposal-type, group project. Lots of reading and most of the grading is done through writing assignments. He was fair with grading, if you follow the rubric in the assignments you'll do well.

I loved Joe as a teacher, it seems based off of other reviews Ive seen here that his classes didnt agree with everyone. Personally, Ive enjoyed his 3500 and found it rather valuable and intriguing. Hes more than well respected in his field and most definitely knows his stuff. I never once found his personality anything but passionate and caring

If you can avoid taking ENR 3500 do it at all costs. It is the equivalent of a graduate class level of work. There is a semester long group project that requires pages and pages of work with due dates throughout the semester and a presentation as the final exam, along with 5 separate written exams and weekly quizzes.

Dr. Campbell is one of those professors who really makes you work, but also makes you learn something at the same time. His classes (both ENR3500 and RURLSOC4500) were some of the hardest classes I've taken at OSU, but they were also my favorites. He challenges you and I appreciated his teaching style so much now that I am applying what I learned!

This class makes me want to scream. Prof is narcissistic and makes us read/write about stuff he has written. Horribly structured. Group project is a main portion of our grade. Lectures are boring, and you can barely hear him in the back half of the room. Seats are somewhat assigned, so you can't move closer. Does not care about you or your concerns

I don't recommend taking 3500 with Campbell. He seems like a good enough guy, but the way that class is structured and his lecture style is awfully boring, and unnecessarily time consuming. He takes an hour to describe something that should only take 25 minutes, and making attendance mandatory + group work during a pandemic? Not the move.

Recently taking this class I felt that Prof Campbell was a great prof! He used class time often to allow for peer interaction as well as often keeping lecture open for questions about the material. There is a large project throughout the semester but it ties in the course content to allow for an understanding of application. Great Class!

I absolutely loved this class, Campbell was actually passionate about what he was teaching and actually cared if we were understanding the material. A large portion of the class is a group project but I found it super useful and I learned more in his class than I have from all of the other classes I have taken. Only good things to say about him!

A lot of these reviews are completely wrong , or at the very least outdated. I had professor Campbell last semester and he was amazing. We did a long (but totally doable) semester project that incorporated what we were learning very well. I had 2 group mates who sucked and held us back. Despite this, Joe was accommodating and worked with us on it.
Everything is group based, but he sucks at explaining things during lectures. Reverse lecture style with a lot of group discussion on relatively unimportant things

Prof Campbell seems nice enough, but this class was not my favorite. The group projects were a little overwhelming, but I got a good group so I lucked out. The tests aren't awful, but you do need to know your stuff. Lectures can be kind of boring.
Class was just him saying empty words with no real meaning. His answer to every question I had was "that's subjective". Thanks, Joe, I learned nothing.

This class is hard but not impossible. It's all about who is in your group for the semester project. Lecture's DRAG ON forever but sometimes they are interesting. Probably don't take this class as an elective unless you really like community development.

ENR 3500 was not a great experience. Much of the class was a group project that was a burden to do and did not help me personally understand the class. He is a nice person and knows the material but I would not want to necessarily have him for another class based on how he teaches, nothing personal

Dr. Campbell is pretty cool. He is super underrated and loves what he does. A lot of people don't like this class because it's not the science they're used to or like but it is still really interesting. The group project is a hassle because it's time-consuming. Overall I really like the class and it is an underrated subject in environmental science

Dr. Campbell is a great guy. He's really passionate and his lectures are engaging even when the material is dull. If you speak up during class he will love you. He makes study guides for all his exams and if you just study them for an hour or two you'll probably ace the test.

Dr. Campbell is a great guy and really tries hard to make the course interesting. He's always prepared for lecture. He is pretty strict when it comes to being late and getting credit for attendance checks. I think he's a fair grader, but the class is set up to give TAs more power in grading which isn't best for this level class so note that!

Was an awful professor. He does random attendance checks and if you walk in 10 seconds passed the start time, you are late. What made this even more unfair was that his class was on West Campus and my previous class was on South Campus. Does not give good feedback, lectures were irrelevant to projects. He was very unorganized.

Quickly turned into one of my least favorite classes I've taken at OSU. Tests were unreasonably hard, and attendance policy is absolutely absurd. I was showed up to class one minute late twice and was denied attendance sheet. Some days he'll take attendance later so it's all a guessing game.  Good luck. Also gets furious if you leave class early.

This is by far the worst class I have taken so far. Avoid this professor at all costs! He's not very nice, there is way too much work! Lectures and exams are close to the projects but are typically not usable in the project... seems unrelated. Exams are horrible save your money take 3400 instead!

My group spent a lot of time working on the class project and still received an 80%, When we questioned this grade we were not given any helpful tips on how to improve our grade in the future. On top of this i got 20% more knocked off for forgetting to turn in a 5 min. peer review which was not included in the original syllabus. Completely unfair!

He's an alright professor, don't get me wrong, but he expects too much out of his class though, and is very vague when it comes to group projects. Expecting 6 students to be able to meet outside of class is a little excessive. His lectures are also horribly put together and unorganized. Stressful class for the criteria being taught.

The project forces you to apply the info you learn in lecture in a "real" community. Those who rate it badly are probably use to/looking for classes that allow you to cram the night before & regurgitate slides onto exams. This will actually force you to learn things - a rare situation in the American education structure.

This teacher is really hard. Would not recommend this class at all. More than 50% of the grade is based off group projects and if you get stuck with a crappy group you might as well drop the class. He's is anal about people showing up on time or if you have to leave early. At all costs avoid this teacher and class

Really unorganized lecture and the group project is terrible and unorganized (especially if your group sucks). Expects students to be able to get 6 people to meet outside of class for the projects and gives very vague descriptions of the criteria for it. Most stressful class I have this semester and I'm taking Ochem. Avoid it!

Joe is a great guy and an outstanding professor. 50% of your grade will come from a semester-long group project where you are in charge of a community. This project is tough with strict grading but the 3 short tests are easy.

It's a really good class if you put in the effort.  The content is interesting and valuable to EEDS majors.  He is down to earth and really easy to get in touch with- if you put in the effort to talk to him he will make plenty of time to help.

Lecture seemed disorganized and too fast. No opportunity for extra credit. Random attendance checks. Exams aren't really cumulative. Group project was terribly difficult to get a good grade because he's hard grading.

summary_comment: Professor Cook is known for making General Education science courses accessible, particularly for non-science majors, with clear lectures and opportunities for extra credit. However, opinions vary; some find her classes challenging and less engaging, while others appreciate her approachable teaching style and willingness to help students.
summary_comment_short: Professor Cook offers a manageable and accessible General Education course, particularly suitable for non-science majors, with clear lectures, opportunities for extra credit, and multiple attempts on exams. However, her teaching style varies among students, with some finding her lectures and slides less engaging and more challenging to study from.

Ratings.comment: Best science GE you could ask for. Asynchronous lectures, weekly problem sets that are really easy as long as you have paid even a little attention and have the textbook. LOTS of opportunity for extra credit. Three exams plus a final, which is kind of a lot but since the class is online you are allowed to use the textbook/your notes.

I didnt like her teaching. You could barely see her notes she wrote on the board (depending on where you sat) and you cant study her powerpoints b/c theyre all just pictures. You cant miss class b/c she does tophat. Tests are difficult - she uses trick questions sometimes so you really have to know the material to do well.

Dr. Cook makes this class manageable because it's a GE and for non-science majors, it's a great option. Lectures are easy to follow, but take notes. Go to class for the TopHat points (3 lowest are dropped though). Exams are taken alone and with the class, but not easy A's. Don't need the book but it provides good supplemental info so I'd recommend.

Dr. Cook knows that this is a GenEd class and does not make the class ridiculously hard. Midterm and final you take twice: solo and group. She is super funny and cares a lot about her students. Don't buy the textbook, pay attention in lecture and review the TopHat. Easy A, interesting topics.

Her classes are not interesting but you can't skip because she will give you some tophat questions. Homeworks are difficult as well. She will give out many extra credits but only affect the overall grade slightly.

For a non-science major, she was the most helpful and clear science professor I've had. Lectures are easy to follow, and tophat is a daily activity that can help boost your grade. There are 2 exams, midterm and final, and you take each exam twice. Once by yourself and once with anyone or everyone in the room, where you are free to talk. Easy GE.

Professor Cook is fun to have as one of the professors for a class like 2155. She gives a solid overview of the topics and uses the chalkboard for most of the items she wants you to write down so it rarely moves too fast. When preparing for exams, she is receptive to questions and happy to help. Reading the textbook as a supplement helps too.

Not a great prof, lectures were boring. Most of her slides are pictures so don't rely on those to study from. Both exams students  got 2 attempts, 1st by yourself and 2nd you can take with the class if you speak up about it; took the average of the 2. Take advantage of extra credit and go to class for participation points on top hat.

Very easy class.  If you show up and actively pay attention you will do fine.  I barely used the book.  I actually wish I did not buy the book.  The workbook makes that class seem like it is a grade-school science class but it actually helped the most.  If you do the pages (even if she doesn't collect some of them) you will do fine on the tests.

She thinks her class is more than just a GEC. Her tests are hard and she doesn't give study guides. Her slides are mostly pictures so good luck studying those. You don't need the book since she doesn't base her class off of it. You do need her little worksheet book even though she barely collects them.

summary_comment: Professor MacKay is known for her rigorous approach, requiring significant time commitment despite being a 1-credit class. While some students found her knowledgeable and caring, others noted challenging assignments and delayed grading. Overall, the class demands substantial effort but is considered manageable and rewarding.
summary_comment_short: Professor MacKay is known for her rigorous approach, requiring significant time and effort, though many find her classes manageable with diligent study. She is highly regarded for her depth of knowledge and caring nature towards her students, despite the challenging workload and strict grading criteria.

Ratings.comment: This was a 1 credit hour class that she explicitly said should take the same amount of time as a 3 credit hour class. Points were taken off for the smallest things on every assignment. She did not follow the syllabus that she gave to us and she did not grade things until usually a month after we submitted them.

Really great professor; incredibly knowledgeable. Can fit more content into the last ten minutes of lecture than some of my professors can in 55 minutes. If you know how to do the homework you can do the problems on the exam. Study conceptual stuff for the exams also. Lot of work for the class but it's very doable.
Great professor who cared about her students! Homework was difficult, but she always posted similar problems online. If you study and understand the homework,  you will do fine on the exams.

I really liked Professor MacKay! I thought she was straight forward and seemed like she genuinely cared about her students. This tech elec was the first time the school offered such a course and I would definitely retake it again with her. I hope to have her as one of my teachers again in the future.

SEI.Subject: CIVILEN
SEI.Class Name: Professional Aspects of Civil and Environmental Engineering

SEI.Subject: CIVILEN
SEI.Class Name: Professional Aspects of Civil and Environmental Engineering

SEI.Subject: CIVILEN
SEI.Class Name: Professional Aspects of Civil and Environmental Engineering

summary_comment: Dr. Pieterson's teaching was generally perceived as ineffective, with students noting that she struggled to engage with the material and often relied solely on slides without providing additional context or answering questions. Many found the class extremely challenging and frustrating, with low support offered even during health crises. Overall, her teaching approach was seen as unsatisfactory and detrimental to student learning.
summary_comment_short: Dr. Pieterson's teaching was generally perceived as ineffective, with students noting that she often struggled to engage with the material and was unable to provide meaningful answers to student questions. Many found her class to be poorly organized and extremely challenging, with a focus on a few high-stakes exams and confusing lab activities.

Ratings.comment: This class was primarily taught by Dr. Lanno, but when Dr. Pieterson taught, it seemed like she did not know what she was doing. She would only read directly from the class slides and spoke as if she didn't understand the material. When students would ask her questions, she sometimes could not provide an answer because she didn't know.

She cares about no one but herself. I got covid, was not provided any support when I quarantined. When I got back to class I went to her for help and she strait up said "There is absolutely nothing I can do for you". So I tried to struggle my way back to being caught up with the course, I withdrew from the class. Don't ever have her as a  teacher.
I honestly don't know why most students don't like her. I learned a lot with Dr. Pieterson. You have to work hard on her classes, but that's expected for college students.

If you have the option to choose another profesor for Bio 151 do it!! This is the hardest class you will ever take in life . You will constantly be confused, frustrated and feeling hopeless. She doesnt teach the material well at all. There isnt enough homework to boost your grade so your grades will depend on 3 or 4 exams and then the final,run!

Dr. Corrie's portion of this class was very unorganized. It was hard to understand how each of her lectures fit together. There was only one exam. She is a VERY slow grader. A benefit is there is no extra things you have to buy for this class.
Hardest Class I have ever taken, if you are gonna work at NASA you need this professor, if not I suggest someone else.

Too much readings and count for your grades. The class materials are boring and pointless. Participation is mandatory and worth large amount of points. Too many small assignments that are easy to miss. The lab activities are confusing. Avoid it!

summary_comment: Professor Matthews is highly regarded for his comprehensive knowledge and engaging lectures on wildlife and forestry, with students praising his informative and well-structured slides. He is described as a very nice and respectful educator who goes out of his way to assist students, though some note that sitting towards the front helps with his occasional soft endings. Exams are challenging, but he offers extra credit opportunities to support learning.
summary_comment_short: Professor Matthews is highly respected for his deep knowledge and engaging lectures on wildlife and forestry, with students praising his informative slides and willingness to assist in research. His approachable and respectful demeanor makes him a favorite among students, though some note that his softening voice at the end of sentences can be challenging for those seated towards the back.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Matthews taught the wildlife and forestry parts of this class. He's super smart and definitely knows what he's talking about. He's also a super nice person. His lecture slides are very informative and easy to review. There is extra credit if you attend for a certain number of days, which would be recommended because the exams are pretty hard.

Dr. Matthews is so nice and respectful to every student and every comment made in lecture. The only problem is he trails off in volume at the end of some sentences, so sit towards the front. He explains things so well and his lecture slides are very well thought out and easy to go back and review from.
Awesome professor. I just wish he wasn't so darn distractingly handsome!
Smart professor who is willing to help you find research you are interested in.

He taught the wildlife part of Intro to FFW. The class itself is pretty straightforward. There are random attendance days, and if you show up to at least 13 of them you get full participation points. There is one project, but no papers. Exams are not easy but there are extra credit opportunities.

SEI.Class Name: Principles of Wildlife Ecology and Management

summary_comment: Professor Tonra is highly regarded for his passion and enthusiasm, particularly about birds, making his lectures engaging and accessible even for complex topics. Students appreciate his clarity, intelligence, and willingness to help, noting that while the course can be rigorous, especially for undergraduates, his use of curves and detailed lab work supports learning. His ability to moderate discussions effectively and provide valuable guidance, especially in preparation for future endeavors, further enhances his teaching quality.
summary_comment_short: Professor Tonra is highly engaging and passionate about his subject, making his lectures entertaining and accessible even for challenging topics. He is known for his thorough knowledge and dedication, which students appreciate through his effective teaching methods and helpful resources like labs and field trips.

Ratings.comment: This guy loves birds and he loved talking about birds. If you like birds you will love him. If you don't love birds you'll probably still like him. Entertaining lectures and very friendly.

Dr. Tonra is ver passionate about his specialty and it shows in his lectures. He is very clear and enthusiastic which makes a lecture heavy class more accessible. This class is all pop quizzes and tests so definitely don't skip, and be sure to study for exams. Tests get curved, and the content is not extremely difficult.
Pretty average prof. Really likes birds. A little bit boring, but he occasionally makes some funny jokes if you're paying attention.

Dr. Tonra's lectures were spot on. He was clear and very interesting. You can tell he is both intelligent and a very hard worker. His labs were so helpful in identification of avian species and the semester project was really neat! He is genuine and helpful to anyone willing to ask. I seriously loved this class.

Tough on undergraduates in a grad level course, though he is more lenient with curves. Makes lecture enjoyable, even at 8am, and his field trips were wonderful. Very knowledgeable and loves teaching. The end-of-the-year panel for graduates was the some of the best help I've gotten from a class in preparing for my future.

This class was a discussion based graduate level course. Professor Tonra provided effective moderation of discussion without dominating the discussion and provided clarification for hard to understand material. He has an extensive knowledge of the class subject (animal migration) which was evident from the quality of the discussions.

summary_comment: Professor Williams is a knowledgeable and passionate lecturer who delivers entertaining and informative content, though his classes are primarily lecture-based with occasional pop quizzes. While students appreciate his enthusiasm and willingness to help, the lack of interactive elements and early morning scheduling can make the experience less enjoyable. His teaching style and content are best suited for those who prefer a traditional lecture format and are willing to put in the effort to study the material thoroughly.
summary_comment_short: Professor Williams is known for his lecture-heavy teaching style, which he delivers with clear passion and occasional humorous flair. His lectures are engaging, and he demonstrates genuine care for his students, though some find the material can be tedious and the course timing challenging.

Ratings.comment: Definitely very lecture heavy but he clearly enjoys what he teaches. Entertaining lectures and will occasionally show up in the hardest outfit you've ever seen.

Lecture heavy course with pop quizzes so you cannot skip. the content is extremely manageable but study for tests, and they will be curved as well. The content can be heavy and tedious but Professor Williams is passionate and it shows.
No class participation, even in small groups, just him talking at the class. Goodluck trying to reach him outside of class too.

Funny professor, great at explaining things. Passionate about his subject. I genuinely felt like he cared about us as students, and he was pretty forgiving. Would've enjoyed it more if I hadn't taken it so early in the morning. He co-taught the class, and I was always excited when he was the one lecturing.

Dr. Williams knows his subject. He is very good at answering questions. The course I had him in was an upper level class, which he taught at an intro level. It was not worth the time spent in the class. Exams were poorly written, but the TA corrected for when the entire class would give the same wrong answer. I expected more from the class.

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

summary_comment: Professor Bruskotter's classes, particularly ENR 3400 and ENR 5649, are often described as challenging and dry, with some students finding them nearly unbearable due to the use of Tophat and specific quiz questions. However, he offers flexible exam formats and helpful readings that can lead to high grades with sufficient preparation. Overall, while the material can be dense and the format rigorous, many find the class manageable and even interesting with dedicated effort.
summary_comment_short: Professor Bruskotter's classes are often described as challenging and dry, but many students find them manageable due to generous exam conditions and helpful readings. However, some students find the material and quizzes extremely difficult and time-consuming, with a high emphasis on detailed preparation and technology use like Tophat and Packback.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Bruskotter is a very fascinating individual if you can get to know him behind the content he teaches. I have taken ENR 3400 and ENR 5649 with him, and while they can be a bit dry, they are still interesting. I rarely did the readings, but he gives 3 hours to take his exams at home, so you can have notes by your side. I ended up with over a 100.

While this class is inherently dry, Professor Bruskotter makes it almost unbearable. The lectures are mind-numbingly boring, he uses Tophat for participation, and quizzes and exams are fairly difficult. My biggest gripe is the use of Packback, where you have to submit 1 question and 3 answers each week, which are then graded by AI. Busy work class.

Class is pretty boring and the professor uses tophat. Will assign 40-page chapters for one class. Has reading quizzes every other week but you will forget all the material from the week before and not do well on the quiz. Quiz questions are also very specific. Find a different professor for this class if you have to take it.

This was ridiculous. Every class you were supposed to come having read at minimum 3 readings, which all turn out to be 20+ pages. There are really difficult, vague quizzes via an app that hardly ever loads because there is no service in AG buildings, which they have no sympathy for. Tests are super long and designed to trick you. AWFUL class.

If you attend class, getting an A should be no problem. The assigned readings are very helpful for learning the material but not necessary for good performance. This was an interesting class with plenty of applications outside of the environmental realm.

summary_comment: Professor Dietsch is generally perceived as a caring instructor who genuinely engages with her students and provides ample time for assignments, though her lectures are often described as lengthy and sometimes disconnected from the assigned readings. While some students find her classes easy and the material accessible, others criticize her for being politically biased, disorganized, and overly long-winded, with many recommending to avoid her classes unless absolutely necessary.
summary_comment_short: Professor Dietsch is generally perceived as a kind and caring instructor who genuinely wants students to understand the material, though her lectures are often described as boring and disorganized, with little connection between her discussions and assigned readings. Students find the class easy, with straightforward quizzes and manageable projects, but warn that the course can lack structure and clarity.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Dietsch is fine. She's incredibly nice and willing to help but her classes are terribly boring and often times the assigned readings have nothing to do with what she discusses in class. The class is very easy to do well in though because all of the quizzes are online and are essentially open note. some big projects though but overall easy.

Easy A. Barely goes over material. Very politically biased and her lectures are riddled with circular points. 5% Material and 95% trying not to offend or upset anyone for any reason at all.

Just skip.

Dr Dietsch genuinely cares about the subjects she teaches. She often expands well beyond the content on the powerpoints she presents. Assignments are in the syllabus and she gives ample time to complete them. She also always adds to and provides meaningful feedback to class participation. Given this is an intro course and she treats it as such.

Was scared by the previous comments and ratings of her, but really wanted to take the class. I took a chance. The chance I took was worth it. I love this class. I enjoy learning the material of this class. I understand the previous comments that her lectures are long, but you can tell she cares and she does show her personality in the lectures.

The worst professor I've ever had. She was a nice woman but lectures were boring and the course was incredibly disorganized (there was no syllabus until 2 weeks into the semester). She is long-winded and any info is vague at best. You do not need to attend class or do the readings. It's an easy A but you will not gain anything from this prof

One of the most confusing professors I've ever had. She always requires us to turn in assignments by her deadline, but frequently misses her deadlines set for grading and putting up the week's content. Also, don't expect to get all the information about an assignment until a day before it's due, or a few days after. Extremely unorganized.

She is very vague, and frankly comes off as insecure. She wastes most of the class time talking about stuff that doesn't matter. Getting information about upcoming assignments from her is impossible until right before their due. Worst teacher I've had ever! Since kindergarten.

She is the most vague, unspecific, and long winded professor I have ever had. She beats around the bush so much it's like pulling teeth to get information from her. She spent 2 minutes talking about how she's not going to promise a study guide because that means different things to different people, but she might provide something etc etc.

Great professor. She cares about her students. She is tough but fair. Would definitely take it again. I feel that I got my money back for sure, which I couldn't say about many other classes here at OSU.

Grading was inconsistent between students and between assignments. Would give a grading rubric, but wouldn't use it. Would use incorrect answers for grading. Learned more going over the exam review sheets than I did from class, readings, and assignments. By the end of the semester, found that less effort netted higher grades on assignments.

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Research Design for the Environmental Social Sciences

summary_comment: Professor Pintor is highly regarded for her exceptional teaching clarity and ability to inspire students effectively without overburdening them. She is known for her accessibility both inside and outside the classroom, making her a valuable resource for students. Her passion for fisheries is evident in her lectures, which are comprehensive yet challenging, with extra credit opportunities available for those who engage actively.
summary_comment_short: Professor Pintor is highly regarded for her exceptional teaching clarity and ability to inspire her students without overburdening them. She is known for her accessibility both inside and outside the classroom, and her passion for the subject matter is evident in her lectures.

Ratings.comment: dr. pintor is one of the best instructors i have ever had the privilege of learning under. she teaches very clearly and brings out the best of her students without ever pushing too hard. outside of the classroom, she is immensely helpful and accessible. i would blindly recommend any course she offers to any student i encounter.
This was a really good class! I took the honors section where we had weekly discussions where Dr. Pintor moderated, and they were so interesting and engaging.

Dr. Pintor is a good professor. She is super nice and definitely knows what she's talking about. The class was very lecture heavy and there was a lot crammed into it. Her focus was the fisheries side of the class and she was passionate about it. There is extra credit for attendance so take advantage of it because the exams are pretty hard.
Good professor, teaches a few courses. Offers some extra credit opportunities. One of the best professors in ENR. Take notes of what she annotates in her slides in class.

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Forestry, Fisheries, and Wildlife

summary_comment: Professor Gehrt is highly regarded for his passion and extensive knowledge in wildlife studies, making his class engaging and informative. Students find the material manageable with consistent study, appreciating the detailed guidelines provided for assignments. While some note that the group project can be challenging, overall, his teaching quality is praised.
summary_comment_short: Professor Gehrt is highly regarded for his passion and extensive knowledge in wildlife topics, making the class engaging and informative. While the species identification component requires consistent effort, the detailed guidelines make the course manageable. However, some students note that the group project can be challenging, and there could be room for improvement in responding to emails.

Ratings.comment: This was by far my favorite class that I have taken at Ohio State. Dr. Gehrt is very passionate about wildlife & is a wealth of knowledge regarding the topics which he teaches. This course requires species ID, but it is very doable with a bit of studying each day. Guidelines for assignments are outlined in detail! Great class/professor, overall!

This was my favorite class I have taken at OSU. I did not find it too difficult, however, I was very interested in the topic. The group project sucked, mostly because my group was not great. My only complaint is Dr. Gehrt is not the best at answering emails.

summary_comment: Professor Londo's teaching quality is mixed, with lectures being online and not required for in-person labs, which are described as fun and skill-building. However, many students found her disorganized, condescending, and unhelpful during in-person sessions, with grading issues reported. Despite these criticisms, some appreciated her flexibility and willingness to help with questions.
summary_comment_short: Professor Londo's teaching quality is mixed; while her lab sections are praised for being engaging and skill-focused, her lectures are largely considered unnecessary for in-person labs, and she is often described as disorganized and condescending. Her grading practices are inconsistent, with some students reporting ungraded assignments and final exams being submitted without full assessment.

Ratings.comment: Basically, just show up for labs. All the lectures are online and not needed for the in-person labs. Only actually saw the professor twice and she was quite rude and not very helpful to the students. TA was nice but didn't always have solutions to issues. My final grade was uploaded into Buckeye Link without my final project or exam being graded.

Carmen page was disorganized. Not even sure my final exam was factored into my final grade, as I have my official grade in the app and my exam has not been graded in Carmen. Took literally over a month to grade one midterm. The lab of this class is actually really fun, though. Felt like we were learning real skills. Lectures were good.
Does not put in grades! Gives you a final grade without even calculating half of the work you do! The lab with the TA is great and really fun, but she is a condescending mess.
Very unorganized and also condescending to students. The lab section with a TA goes well , but the rest of the class is disorganized.

One of the best profs for encouraging marketable skills. She focuses on having projects be like work assignments - you aren't supposed to work directly off a rubric, so she is very fair with grading. Like a boss with a work assignment, if you're willing to ask questions and communicate, she is extremely flexible and will make herself available.

While there is some criticism of her being disorganized, she's a fantastic professor because she works hard to make sure everyone understands the topic, and will cover things multiple times and give plenty of opportunities to ask questions. Show up, take notes, do the practice problems she suggests, and you will do well.

While I generally enjoyed this class, Dr Londo's teaching style was not it. She was utterly unorganized, and on multiple occasions would throw a project at us that we had 0 info on how to do. That being said, tests were open note and open book, and were incredibly easy. While she isn't a good professor, she's a lovely and very understanding person.

She is pretty straightforward and a good professor. Lecture attendance isn't mandatory but lab is. The class takes some extra effort if you have never done anything with QGIS software before but once you get the hang of it it isn't too bad. Tests were online and no homework except for lab writeups.
She keeps it real

ENR 3700 itself is a very manageable course. Lecture is mostly concept-based, if you can memorize terms, you'll be fine on the exam. For lab, you basically follow instructions that walk you through, and I actually found it really enjoyable. Dr. Londo herself is relatively unpleasant and can come off as grumpy and condescending. Dr. Zhao is a G tho
Dr. Londo is phenomenal. She is a great educator and is SO willing to help her students.

Dr. Londo has been one of the worst professors I've had. Her lectures are so hard to follow because of how scattered she is. When you go to ask her questions about the material she throws at you she talks down to you as if she has no idea how you couldn't understand the material. I gave up asking for clarification cause she always confused me more.

Lectures have no slides or notes. Instead she draws on a tablet while we watch, sometimes pausing to Google things while screen-sharing. Mandatory Zoom labs with random classmates who are just as lost as you. She makes things seem more difficult than they are, which is the opposite of a professor's job. Don't take this class if you don't need it.

Dr. Londo is disorganized. She provides little feedback, if any, on labs. Her lectures are very scattered and confusing. She often jumps from one subject to another on tangents. You would be better off studying forest biometrics yourself than taking this course.

Dr. Londo was VERY approachable and understanding; mostly annoying for me because I don't particularly like GIS and since I have a mac I had to use a remote browser to connect virtually to the computer lab. I did not attend 1 lecture and got a 99%. Tests (2) are open note. Projects are draining and can be confusing. 3 hr mandatory zoom labs.

Dr. Londo was by far the best professor I've had at OSU!! She is very sweet and very understanding! She will work one-on-one with you if you are feeling behind and wants to see you succeed. Although, she won't just give you the answers right away on labs, she wants you to work for it and really learn what you're doing. I love her and respect her!

This is an easy class if you are keeping up. Lectures are of little value on their own. You will need to figure some things out for yourself and within the lab. Will give quiz grades for attendance on low attendance days. You are unlikely to get much from the class, as it is a brief intro to GIS. But, Dr. Londo does well at getting you started.

summary_comment: Professor Ard is known for teaching easy classes with minimal required reading and a focus on lecture notes for exams. Her courses cover interesting topics, particularly the social aspects of natural resources and history. However, students have noted issues with organization, unresponsiveness to emails, and a generally disorganized approach to assignments and lectures.
summary_comment_short: Professor Ard offers an easy class with minimal reading and homework, focusing heavily on lecture notes for tests. Lectures are generally interesting but can be disorganized, and while the professor is described as sweet and approachable, some students found her unresponsive to emails and lacking in passion for the subject matter.

Ratings.comment: Society and Natural Resources was a really easy class. No reading or outside notes required. Just go to lectures and you're fine for tests. Tests are open note and all in the lecture notes. We had to do a poster presentation at the end that was a little unorganized but overall great class.

Dr. Ard is amazing! Not too hard of homework and she usually gives time in class to complete it. There's an overall wicked problem essay group project at the end, but its easy grading. The course topics are also super interesting and talks about the social aspect of history.

Professor Ard is very sweet but did not seem very passionate about what she was teaching. She does not reply to emails about questions from the lecture and came off as a little rude when she told my class that she will not respond. The class is pretty easy but she is disorganized and would assign things randomly with little notice.
Dr. Ard was very unorganized, but a fine professor. She and the TA were awful at answering emails, and I missed an A by them not communicating with each other very well.
Were not many assignments for this class, and when there were they were mainly 5 points or less. Lectures connect on a personal level and she welcomes but does not require participation.

Her lectures are interesting and projects are pretty easy. Homework is also really easy. Attend every lecture unless its online. Most of the exam questions are verbatim from the lectures and what she says so take good notes on important points. Referencing only the PowerPoints during exams will get you mediocre grades.

She is a great person outside of class and funny. Her assignments are very easy, however, her lectures go all over the place and she gets distracted easily. Her TA grades everything and is a very tough grader.
Meh. She was pretty unhelpful and hard to contact, and her class felt a bit messy and disorganized. Still an easy A.

Kerry is a captivating and inspiring professor and I suggest taking a course with her if possible. The only critique I have is that the final project was poorly explained at first, but it isn't too bad. Lectures are extremely interesting and this class is easy if you put in a bit of effort.

The lectures got boring towards the end but the Professor has a lot of passion and cares about her work and students. There are assignments for each class, due 2 days after that lecture, and they are easy and not worth many points. 3 exams and a final project (which couldve been explained better).Exams are fine as long as you take notes in class.

This class was horrible. Lectures are worthless. She posts things a couple days before they're due, so you never know when you'll have things due. The final group project is incredibly vague. Don't expect to be able to ever talk to her, as she doesn't respond to any emails. She turned this into a sociology class, and rarely mentions the environment

Dr. Ard was a very good professor. Lectures were interesting and required class participation. She did Kahoots that were for extra credit so make sure you show up to class. As long as you review her powerpoint and your notes the tests were fairly easy. Make sure to pay attention to the examples she gives in class. There is a group project as well.

Very respected and caring of the students and the materials taught. Very personable and approachable. Class is lecture heavy and the tests reflect it. As long as you review the slides, the tests will be easy.

Love Kerry Ard. Her lectures are interesting and easy to follow. The exams do control the grade a lot, though, and I underestimated how hard the exam would be. Be SURE to study closely the lecture notes and write down the examples she gives. She is also strict about deadlines and doesn't accept late work. Fairly easy A if you put the effort in.

She is super sweet and really helpful. A lot of random assignments in class which help boost your grade. She does random kahoot quizzes some days which count as extra credit so go to class! The final project is incredibly confusing and unnecessary but it's not too much work outside of class, just difficult to communicate with your group.

She's the best! My favorite class AU19-- interesting, fresh, & relevant lectures for someone studying the environment. Attendance is important as midterms are lecture-heavy (pretty easy though) and most of the extra credit comes from Kahoot quizzes, but she doesn't take formal attendance. Lots of small assignments and 1 group project. Fairly easy A

Professor Ard is a great lecturer. Her class was really interesting and well presented. I didnt know what to expect when I took this class, but Im glad I did. Prof Ard is very passionate and intelligent. The class was graded off a few things and exams are lecture based. The poster project isnt difficult as long as you put forth effort

This class was super interesting and Dr. Ard was very passionate about the topics we discussed. You definitely want to go to class because the exams are strongly based off of the lectures. There are also extra credit Kahoot quizzes.

Super easy tests. Frequent attendance checks (short groupwork or Kahoot quizzes). She is so sweet and cares a lot about what she teaches. Not always objective in the way she teaches controversial topics. The final is a poster project, it was very unguided and the requirements were unclear, but it was her first semester teaching ENR2300.

She was awesome! Her lectures could be boring sometimes but overall she is really funny and had a lot of things in the class I never thought about. There is a final poster project which is easy but the rubric was really unclear. Overall she is an easy-grader and really fun in class!

Professor Ard is energetic and shows enthusiasm in her teaching. Exams are based off of lecture down to the fine details, so show up and pay attention! Final project is vague and more frustrating than it needs to be. Interesting content, important to participate.
The lectures were interesting. She was nice and really enthusiastic which made lectures more fun. The final research project was frustrating because of my group but fine overall.

She's a great professor, but at the beginning of class during syllabus week, she said that attendance was non-mandatory. It is technically, but not if you want to pass the class. Tests are HEAVILY lecture- and example-based. Go to class, pay attention, and participate and you will do fine. Very nice woman, and interesting lecturer.

This class is awful.  It's held in a movie theater far away from any other class I take.  Parking won't happen for under 15 dollars a class.  The class itself is boring and doesn't look at all like what my friends in another section of the class are learning.  Dr. Ard is beyond rude.  No office hours.  The video final project is a waste of time.

summary_comment: Professor Jones is known for being very friendly and willing to help students, though his classes can be lengthy and sometimes枯燥乏味。尽管他能够及时解答问题并在课内外提供帮助，但学生的反馈也指出他的邮件回复速度较慢，有时会导致错过重要信息。此外，课程作业和考试难度较大，尤其是每周的测验和实验室报告，需要投入较多时间和精力。
summary_comment_short: Professor Jones is known for being very nice and willing to help students, though his classes can be lengthy and sometimes dull. Despite the challenging quizzes and extensive lab work, students appreciate his readiness to assist and provide clear feedback.

Ratings.comment: This class is dull and long. He is very nice and is willing to help everyone. The only gripe I have about him personally is his response time for emails. I emailed him about a fatal error in our quiz and he never got back to me, not even in class. Sometimes his quiz answer selections do not have the correct answer and you have to guess and pray.

Sandy is an extremely nice guy which makes up for this class that has way too much work for a one hour lab. Although the labs can be tough, he is always willing to sit down and work with you both inside and outside of class time. Very flexible and although the lectures can be long they're all posted to review later as well.

Possibly the dullest class on the planet (even as an ENR major), but Sandy is pretty nice which makes it easier. All of the assignments just kind of suck, but some of the procedures in lab are pretty cool. The class would probably suck no matter what, but Sandy probably makes it suck the least compared to anyone else.

Prior to each lab, you do some reading and watch lectures. There is also a lab report each week. Any questions you have on the lab, Prof. Jones answers in a very clear and concise manner. There are also quizzes each week, which can be tricky. The land use project is also a lot of work, but he gives you ample time to do it. The final is open book
Very relaxed, always ready to assist, always does his best! Always quick to give good feedback when asked questions.

He gives long lectures in lab and weekly quizzes are pretty tough. The lab reports include answering mathematical questions and he will give help if you just ask for it. If you are in the lab, I recommend not leaving after you finish the lab. Stay in the room and work on the report while Professor Jones is still there to help you. Real nice guy

Soil science lab was the class so you had to show up.  He is very smart, knows his material, and is always prepared for class.  The weekly lab reports were very difficult along with the final exam.  Overall, the class wasn't too bad and usually didn't take the full 3 hour time slot.

Teaches lab, so attendance is a must. Very friendly; extremely willing to help. Lectures are long and boring, but the slides are decent. Highly recommend asking TAs for additional help on labs to succeed. Final is very tough; highly unlikely to finish the exam. Be prepared with slides and notes.

summary_comment: Professor Braig is an excellent lecturer who maintains high standards while keeping even mundane topics engaging. He is known for being forgiving with grades and showing understanding of the challenges students face in college, though he expects thoroughness in term papers. Students highly recommend his courses.
summary_comment_short: Professor Braig is an excellent lecturer who maintains engagement even during potentially mundane topics. He is known for being forgiving with grades and showing understanding towards students' challenges, though he expects high standards from term papers.

Ratings.comment: A great lecturer, even when the lecture topics could get dull. Forgiving with grades and understanding of how tough college can be, although he can be more scrutinous with a term paper. Great professor, would highly recommend taking

summary_comment: Professor Berardo is highly regarded for his engaging lectures and ability to make even early morning classes interesting. Students find his exams challenging but manageable with thorough preparation, and many appreciate his willingness to help and respect for diverse opinions. However, his lectures can be dry, and attendance is crucial as missing classes can significantly impact grades.
summary_comment_short: Professor Berardo is highly regarded for his engaging lectures and ability to make even early morning classes interesting. His exams are known to be challenging, but students find them fair and often improve with thorough preparation and attendance.

Ratings.comment: I loved Dr. Berardo! He's an awesome professor. His tests are tough but if you really study it's not an issue. I highly recommend him!

I really liked Berardo, did not do so well on the reading quizzes - I suggest to have the quiz open while reading - exams are average - lots of reading but a good skim through usually does the trick. lecture heavy come to class! great opportunity to really dig down deep into a topic of your choice for the assignment papers.
First 9 answers on an exam were all false if that says anything about his character
I had this as an 8AM, and it was rough. He's a good guy though, and engages the students in his lectures. There's a few papers and the exams are fairly tough, but not impossible.

One of the best professors I've had at OSU. he made a class at 8 am actually interesting. Exams are tough, but review sessions are pretty comprehensive. Really respectful of different opinions. His sarcasm can be difficult to discern sometimes.
Really funny! Berardo is a good professor but lecture material is dry. Worked hard for an A-.

Great professor. Good energy, welcomes feedback, willing to help. Go to EVERY class or prepare to have your grade lowered by 10 percent, you can only miss 3. The weekly online quizzes matter, be sure to get As on all of them. Exams are more reading based than expected.

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Research Design for the Environmental Social Sciences

SEI.Subject: ENR
SEI.Class Name: Frameworks and Theories of Environmental Policy

summary_comment: Professor Groth is generally well-intentioned and approachable, with a focus on student success through easy exams and participation opportunities. However, her classes can be perceived as monotonous due to her tendency to read from slides, which may make them less engaging. Attendance is mandatory, primarily for daily quizzes and class participation.
summary_comment_short: Professor Groth's teaching style is largely lecture-based, with a focus on reading slides, which some find monotonous and boring. While she is described as a kind and supportive instructor who aims to help students succeed, her classes require regular attendance for daily quizzes, and the material is generally easier when attended regularly.

Ratings.comment: I was looking forward to this class but was quickly disappointed. All she does is read the slides to you making it a boring, monotonous class. Attendance is required because she takes quizzes everyday. Tests are fairly easy, just an overall boring class.

Theresa means well. She is super nice and seems like she wants students to do well. The exams are pretty easy as long as you go to class. There are weekly discussion questions, a chance for extra credit, and no long papers or projects. Attendance is taken via TopHat and there are a few pop quizzes.

summary_comment: Professor Thoma excels in sharing extensive knowledge and wisdom in his field, making his lectures informative and engaging despite their length. While his enthusiasm is evident, students advise being prepared for dad humor and bad puns. Overall, he is highly regarded for his teaching quality, with nearly unanimous student satisfaction, as indicated by the willingness of many to take his class again.
summary_comment_short: Professor Thoma excels in sharing his extensive knowledge and passion for his subject matter, making his lectures informative and engaging, though they can be lengthy. Despite occasional dad humor and bad puns, students appreciate his teaching quality and would highly recommend his classes, with one noting a preference for no textbook.

Ratings.comment: Mr. Thoma isn't really a teacher, but he did a good job teaching my class. His lectures are long because he's so into what he studies, and he has lots of knowledge and wisdom to share in his field. Beware of dad humor and bad puns, but he's still pretty funny. 100% would take his class again.  Also, no textbook

summary_comment: Professor Garcia is an effective instructor who simplifies complex sociological theories, making the material accessible even to non-majors. He emphasizes key concepts and terminology, using multiple-choice tests to assess understanding, which allows students to achieve high grades with focused study. Students highly recommend his courses for their clarity and practical approach.
summary_comment_short: Professor Garcia is an effective instructor who simplifies complex sociological theories, making them accessible even to non-majors. His focus on key concepts and multiple-choice tests facilitates understanding and success in the course.

Ratings.comment: Nick is a great instructor. I am not a sociology major student, but he made the material in class easy to understand. Maybe because I took the class in summer, he used multi-choices as test instead of papers. Just remember the important theory and know what those terminologies refers to, you can get an A. I would take his course again if I can.

summary_comment: Professor Henshaw is an excellent instructor who makes lectures engaging and relevant by connecting classroom concepts to real-world issues. His classes are dynamic, with significant emphasis on Top Hat participation and group discussions, requiring consistent attendance for optimal understanding. While the course is not overly challenging, it does demand active engagement to succeed.
summary_comment_short: Professor Henshaw is a highly effective instructor who makes lectures engaging and relevant through humor and real-world applications. His teaching approach emphasizes active participation and discussion, requiring consistent attendance and engagement to succeed, while still maintaining a balanced level of difficulty that is neither overly challenging nor too easy.

Ratings.comment: Great professor. Made lectures funny and interesting, and connected class concepts to real-world problems. Exams cover material during lecture that isn't always on the slides and class is heavy on Top Hat participation/quizzes and group/class discussions, so attendance is important if you want to do well. Overall not too hard but not an easy A.

summary_comment: Professor Henshaw is known for his effective teaching methods and engaging discussions, earning him praise as one of the best teachers at OSU. However, his exams are noted for being extremely challenging, which some students find off-putting despite his overall excellent instructional approach. His classes are heavily reliant on PowerPoint slides, and while some find his lectures enjoyable, others struggle to stay engaged due to the material's relative ease.
summary_comment_short: Professor Henshaw is a highly regarded teacher known for his engaging discussions and comprehensive lectures, though his exams are noted for being challenging. Students appreciate his dedication to the subject matter and his fairness in grading, despite the difficulty level of his assessments.

Ratings.comment: I enjoyed having him as my teacher for ENR 2500. Takes Tophat serious, SO GO TO CLASS! His exams are ridiculously hard! I enjoy the guy but his exams are ridiculous! I wouldn't recommend you take him if there is another teacher that is easier on exams. He is a great teacher but his exams made me hate the class.

Took this class for a GE and it was very easy. The professor was great and his lectures were not bad at all. Learned a lot. Hard to pay attention in class as the material was pretty easy, but he made it sometimes enjoyable to be there
Lots of discussion. Best teacher I've had at OSU!
Heavily ppt slide dependent
Took him for Sustainable Ag/ENR 5600, a discussion based class. I learned a ton and his grading was fair.

summary_comment: Professor Lazar's classes are considered challenging, requiring consistent attendance and thorough note-taking to succeed. Tests are generally straightforward but demand a deep understanding of the material beyond what is provided in vague study guides. While some students find it an "easy A" with sufficient preparation, others report difficult exams with trick questions and frequent participation quizzes.
summary_comment_short: Professor Lazar's classes are generally considered manageable with consistent attendance and thorough note-taking, as her lectures contain crucial information not available elsewhere. However, her exams are known to be challenging with detailed content that goes beyond the provided study guides, requiring significant preparation and engagement with the material.

Ratings.comment: This class was an easy A if you study the powerpoints. You HAVE to attend every lecture because her slides have several blanks and are very lengthy. Tests are easy if you go to class and study the material. Study guides are very vague and in my opinion the material was very dry.

The people who commented below me have NO idea what they are talking about.  Go to class, study the notes thoroughly, and you will get an A.  Tests are not tricky, the answers are directly from the notes.  SO YES, take the class.  Easy A!

Kelly does not make this class easy. In order to get the notes, you must attend every lecture, since there are fill in the blanks on her powerpoints that are posted online. Her tests are straightforward for the most part, but you need to know A LOT more than what is on the study guide. Would recommend finding a different professor if possible.

Whoever said Earth Science was the easiest science class obviously never took it with Kelly. Her exams are extremely tough with trick questions--although she claims there are none. She teaches directly off power points where you have to fill in the blanks on them. She also has numerous participation and pop quizzes every class.

summary_comment: Professor Johnson is perceived as having significant issues with his teaching method, particularly due to his difficult-to-read handwriting on slides, which hinders note-taking for students. His lectures are described as overly advanced and unenthusiastic, with some students finding him boring and assuming his lack of engagement stems from believing his audience already possesses extensive knowledge on the topics covered.
summary_comment_short: Professor Johnson is perceived as having a challenging teaching style, particularly due to his difficult-to-read handwriting on slides, which complicates note-taking for introductory students. Additionally, many find his lectures monotonous and lacking enthusiasm, with some noting that he assumes students have prior extensive knowledge of the subjects.

Ratings.comment: Difficult to read handwriting on slides which makes note taking harder, too specific/advanced for an intro level course when describing certain topics

Chris Johnson thinks he's really good at his job and being innovative and interactive by making the notes blank and writing in the answer during lecture, but his hand writing is so awful you can't read what he writes.  He is also extremely boring, he has no enthusiasm and thinks that everyone already has extensive knowledge on topics.

summary_comment: Professor Bessette is highly regarded for his engaging and humorous teaching style, which makes the class enjoyable. However, his strong liberal views can create a challenging environment for students with conservative perspectives, as it may be difficult to express opposing opinions.
summary_comment_short: Professor Bessette is highly regarded for his engaging and humorous teaching style, which students find enjoyable and effective. However, his strong liberal viewpoints can create an environment where conservative students may feel uncomfortable expressing their opinions.

Ratings.comment: He is a great professor and great guy. If he wasn't funny and cool I would have hated this class. The only thing I didn't like is that he is a heavy liberal. If you are conservative I think you shouldn't take this class because often times it is difficult to voice your opinion.
